About Last Night: Harvey-Pinard notches hat-trick in blowout win

Rafaël Harvey-Pinard's second period hat-trick was the first for a Canadiens rookie in one period since Dick Gamble against the Hawks in 1952.

Published Mar 26, 2023  •  Last updated 1 day ago  •  2 minute read

Rafaël Harvey-Pinard scored his first NHL career hat-trick in an 8-2 blowout win over the Columbus Blue Jackets on Saturday night at the Bell Centre.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Nick Suzuki matched his point total from a year ago with one goal and three assists. Mike Matheson and Mike Hoffman each added three points of their own.

At the Bell Centre to watch the victory: Le Petit Viking Mats Naslund.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Michel Lacroix announcing the third Harvey-Pinard goal was also a memorable moment.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

After Columbus opened scoring 1:32 in, Hoffman responded with the first of six goals on starter Elvis Merzlikins.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Jesse Ylonen gave Montreal the lead with his fourth goal in his last five games.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Columbus tied it up before the end of the first period when Kirill Marchenko hit the top corner before goalie Sam Montembeault sent the net ajar. Upon review, it was considered a good goal.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Harvey-Pinard did all his damage in the second period, starting 13 seconds in.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

The Habs offence came alive with three goals in 9:29, starting with Harvey-Pinard again.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Then Brendan Gallagher scored his first goal since returning from injury.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Harvey-Pinard completed his hat-trick on the power play. The Habs were up 6-2, and Merzlikins left the game with an apparent injury. Michael Hutchinson came in relief the rest of the way.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

The Habs were looking for more in the third period. Alex Belzile sent one out in front that hit a stick and crossed the goal line to give Montreal a 7-2 lead.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Suzuki continued his torrid pace with Montreal’s eighth goal on the night. The captain now has 10 points in his last four games.

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

The Canadiens came in with two wins in their last 10, while the Blue Jackets had won two straight, but Columbus had some scrapes and bruises from playing the night before and it showed. The Sharks have caught up with them for 32nd in league standings, so when it comes to the Connor Bedard sweepstakes, this loss keeps the Blue Jackets at the bottom for another day.

Montreal came into the game sitting in 28th with breathing room at both ends. I’m no soothsayer, but there are a lot of Butterfly Effect/Sliding Doors hypotheticals going down in the Liveblog comments: e.g. winning a single game will guarantee they don’t win the lottery, which will prevent them from getting Bedard, which will ensure another decade of losing. It’s likely the most significant wedge issue in the comments: just how meaningful or meaningless are the results of these games?

  1. Harvey-Pinard becomes Bell Centre darling in whitewash 8-2 win over Columbus

  2. Bruins' A.J. Greer only gets one game for a cross-check to the face

Meanwhile, Suzuki has shaken off some rough patches, and even without consistent linemates will hit a new career-high in points. Has the latest recipient of his sweet passes, Harvey-Pinard, locked up a spot on next October’s starting lineup? He’s up to 12 goals and 17 points in 29 games. Jesse Ylonen is getting hot at the right time and is at least earning a spot in the conversation after looking on the outs early on.

3. “Fun game for the Habs fans. It’s not often the Habs blow out the opposition (or even win). Great game for RHP; would have loved to see him get a 4th goal. Merzlikens played like he got the memo to tank.” -Hermanus Wittebol
2. “Sure, we didn’t need the win, and we know we were playing against Columbus, but it is nice to watch our young guys win a game every so often.” -Bob Taylor
1. “Good results today. We played well and won convincingly. And had/having some good results elsewhere. Currently have #5 spot and FLA now at #14 if the marbles fall as expected.” -Ian London
